div.p: This term is found in BIOGRAPHY PERSONNAME . It must go inside a DATAITEM. PSEUDONYM includes all names -- both proper names and descriptive phrases (for example, A Lover of Her Sex is a pseudonym for Mary Astell) -- if used in publishing or circulating work. This tag has optional attributes of NAMESIGNIFIER, REG, and WROTEORPUBLISHEDAS.
Variations of her given or standard name should be entered as pseudonyms. For example, Margery Louise Allingham published as Louise A.; Maria Abdy published as M. A.

Include ALL pseudonyms ever used by the writer. It is crucial to a literary history of women's writing that we record, with scrupulous accuracy and research, all pseudonyms and enter them within this element in the Biography section of a writerâ€™s entry.
All pseudonyms will have WROTEORPUBLISHEDAS=wrotePublishedAsYes attribute value.
"Written by herself" is not considered a pseudonym but part of the long form of the title.
Anonymous is not a pseudonym, see Authorship.

When the text was published By a Lady, include A Lady as a pseudonym, leaving out the By and capitalizing the A. Do not regularize to Lady, A. (Although By a Lady is counted in PAUTHORSHIP as anonymity rather than pseudonymity because it was at one time so usual.)

The Author of [title] has occasionally been listed as a pseudonym but this practice should be avoided. (Remember to record this title-page identifier in the Writing section under PAUTHORSHIP, using the allusive attribute.)
Question: If she published By a Lady is this a pseudonym? Answer: Yes, A Lady is a pseudonym for the purpose of PERSONNAME. See above practice directive.

Question: She uses By the Author of . . . on title-pages. Is this a PSEUDONYM, and if I enter it as such do I include a TITLE tag? Answer: No, do not normally count this as a pseudonym. If you have some special reason to do so, leave the title untagged.
